name: Acuecucyoticihuati
bio: Aquatic nagual of Chalchiuhtlicue. Goddess of the running water in rivers, streams and waves on the beach. Women in childbirth cry out to her for relief from their pains.

name: Acxomocuil
bio: God of merchants, pulque and sex. Like Tezcatlipoca, he's represented with a snake in place of his foot.

name: Ahkinshok
bio: Guardian of the Bees, Owner of the days or Spirit of the new fire. Linked to the mayan god Xmulzencab.

name: Ahuitzotl
bio: Mix between an otter, a monkey and a dog. He was feared due to his liking of human flesh, especially nails, eyes and teeth. He used the hand on his tail to drown fishermen.

name: Amapan
bio: Patron deity of tlachtli, an aztec game where the ball represented the sun. Servant of Huitzilopochtli, is also associated with warfare.

name: Amimitl
bio: Patron deity of the Otomi's city of Cuitlahuac, he's a minor god of lakes and fish hunters and aspect of Mixcoatl.

name: Atlacoya
bio: Goddess of drought and barren land, associated with the worship of pulque. She represents austerity and despair.

name: Atlaua
bio: Minor god of the domesticated aquatic flow who protects fishermen and archers. His nahual is the quetzal bird.

name: Azcatl
bio: Red ant which helped Quetzalcoatl to give maize, hidden inside a mountain, to feed the gods and humankind.

name: Camaxtli
bio: Tlaxcaltec creator god of hunting, war, fire, fate and hope. His cult merged with Huitzilopochtli

name: Ce Calli
bio: One of the Cihuateteo, the warriors spirits of women who died in childbirth. They accompanied the sun from noon till sundown. Feared, they are also associated with lust and filth.

name: Ce Cuauhtli
bio: One of the Cihuateteo, the warriors spirits of women who died in childbirth. They accompanied the sun from noon till sundown. Feared, they are also associated with lust and filth.

name: Ce Mazatl
bio: One of the Cihuateteo, the warriors spirits of women who died in childbirth. They accompanied the sun from noon till sundown. Feared, they are also associated with lust and filth.

name: Ce Ozomatli
bio: One of the Cihuateteo, the warriors spirits of women who died in childbirth. They accompanied the sun from noon till sundown. Feared, they are also associated with lust and filth.

name: Ce Quiahuitl
bio: One of the Cihuateteo, the warriors spirits of women who died in childbirth. They accompanied the sun from noon till sundown. Feared, they are also associated with lust and filth.

name: Centeotl
bio: Olmec, Totonac and mayan god of fertility. Gender-fluid entity revered by maize farmers but also midwives.
spellings: Cinteotl, Centeocihuatl, Centeal, Centeotltecutli, Cexochitl, Icnopiltzin, Tlatlauhquicenteotl, Tonacajoha, Tonacayohua, Tzinteotl, Xoxouhquicenteotl, Civeles, Temazcalteci. ToNantzin, Cinteotle, Centeocihuati, Cinteotlcihuatl, Cintéotltecuhtli, Cinteohuatl, Cintecutli, Iztaccenteotl
aspect: Tlaloc, Chicomecoatl, Quetzalcoatl, Xipe Totec, Chalchiuhtlicue, Tonatiuh, Xilonen, Xochipilli, Yacatecuhtli

name: Centzon Huitznahua
bio: Southern star gods. With Coyolxauhqui, their sister, they tried to kill their mother, Coatlicue. Huitzilipochtli massacred them, symbolising the sunrise and the disappearance of the stars.
spellings: Centzon Huitznauhtin, Centzonuitznaua, Centzon Huitznahuac, Centzonhuitznahua, Cuahuitlicac, Quauitlicac

name: Chalchiuhtecolotl
bio: Night owl god with fire eyes. Associated with magic and sorcery, he's an aspect or nahual of Tezcatlipoca.

name: Chalchiuhtlatonac
bio: Aspect of the water goddess Chalchiuitlicue, which means "She who shines like jade". She's also a protectof for midwives.

name: Chalchiuhtlicue
bio: Goddess of water, especially running streams, lakes and ocean. Married to Tlaloc (who control the rain from the sky), she's also a patron of birth
spellings: Chalciuhtlicue, Chalchihuitlicue, Chalchiuhcueyeh, Chalchihcueye, Xalxitlikue, Xoxouhqui Ihuipil, Xoxouhqui Icue, Chalchiuh Tlatonac, Chicomecóatl, Chalchiuhicueye, Chalchiuhtlicue, Atl, Matlalcueye, Xixiquipilihui, Matlolcueitl, Chalchiuhtlatonac
aspect: Matlalcueitl, Itzaccihuatl, Acuecucyoticihuati, Centeotl, Yohualticitl, Xilonen, Huixtocihuatl, Ayauhteotl, Atlacoya, Chicomecoatl, Chalchiuhtlatonac, Coatlicue, Tzapatlan Tenen

name: Chalchiutotolin
bio: God of pestilence, disease, disorder, chaos and mystery. This aspect of Tezcatlipoca, depicted as a turkey, cleanse the humans of contamination, absolve them of guilt, and help them to overcome their fate.

name: Chalmecacihuatl
bio: Minor goddess of the underworld and sacrifices and wife of Tzontemoc or Chalmecatecuhtli. She can be depicted as a massive snake guarding the Mictlan.
spellings: Chalmecacihuilt, Chalmeccacihuatl, Chalmecatl, Chalmecatecuchtli, Chachalmecacihuatl, Chalmeca ciuatl

name: Chalmecatecuhtli
bio: God of sacrifice, ruler of one of the nine levels of the underworld. He is closely related to Mictlantecuhtli

name: Chantico
bio: Goddess of hearth, volcanic fires and personal treasure, she's also a patron of goldsmiths. She was transformed into a dog by Tonacatecuhtli fo breaking fast during a religious celebration.

name: Chicomecoatl
bio: Depicted as a young girl, she's a goddess of nourishment and agriculture, especially maize and peas.
spellings: Chiutcoatl, Chicomeccatl, Chicomexochitl, or Chalchiuhcihuatl, Xilonen, Chicomolotzin, Chicomecohuati, Chicome Coatl

name: Chicome Xochitl
bio: Nagual of Xochipilli and god of writing, painting and song, as well as of hallucinogenic plants.

name: Chiconahui Ehecatl
bio: Creator god of minor importance, similar to the four Tezcatlipocas. Second sun in the aztec cosmology, nagual of Ehecatl.
aspect: Tezcatlipoca, Quetzalcoatl, Huitzilopochtli, Xipe Totec, Ehecatl

name: Chiconahui Itzcuintli
bio: Goddess of gem makers, associated with Chantico and Xiuhtecuhtli.
spellings: Tloxipeuhca, Chicoahui Itzcuintli-Chantico, Chiucnahui itzcuintli, Tlappapalo, Papaloxahual

name: Chimalma
bio: Fertility goddess, patron of life and death. She's one of the mother of Quetzalcoatl and wife of Mixcoatl who accompanied the Azteca from Aztlan.

name: Cihuapipiltzin
bio: Goddess who watches over crossroads and attacks men. Embodiment of women who die in childbirth.

name: Cipactli
bio: Primordial earth, symbolised by a monstruous caiman. Tezcatlipoca and Quetzalcoatl dismembered it to create the earth and sky. It's also a guardian of one of the levels of Mictlan.

name: Cipactonal
bio: First man of the fifth sun created by Quetzalcoatl. Inventor of astrology and calendars, he also represents the sun.

name: Citlalatonac
bio: Creator of the stars who lives in the second level of Aztec heaven with his consort, Citlaticue.

name: Citlalicue
bio: Creator goddess of the Milky Way, stars, death, darkness and Earth. Lives in the second level of Aztec heaven with Citlalatonac.

name: Citlatepetl
bio: Jealous lover of Iztaccihuatl, who told her that Popocatepetl, her true love, had died in battle. He became a volcano, known as Pico de Orizaba, to witness their love for eternity.  .

name: Coatlicue
bio: Creator goddess of earth, fire, stars of the southern sky and birth. Depicted as a woman wearing a skirt of snakes, with sharp claws, as she was thirsty for sacrifices. Mother of Huitzilopochtli, she's also the inspiration of the "weeping woman" in mexican folklore.
spellings: Llamateuctli, Coatlantonan, Koatlikueitl, Tēteoh īnnān, Teteto Inan, Toci, Cihuacoatl, Tonantzin, Yohuatlicue, Chihucoatl, Ciucoatl, Chiuacoatl, Quilaztli, Huitzilincuatec, Tititl, Yaocihuatl, Tonantzin, Toci, Teteto Innan, Coatlicue, Quilaztli, Coacihuatl, Coatlan Tenan, Cuauhcihuatl, Tzitzimicihuatl, Cihuacohuatl, Cuaucihuatl, Teoyaominqui, Teoyaotlatohua, Teoyaomqui, Chicomexochitl ou Chalchiuhcihuatl
source: Statue displayed in National Anthropology Museum in Mexico City
aspect: Ilamacihuatl, Itzaccihuatl, Huixtocihuatl, Chalchiuhtlicue, Quilaztli, Ixnextli, Ilancueye, Tlazolteotl, Mayahuel, Xilonen, Chimalma, Itzpapalotl, Xochiquetzal, Omecihuatl, Coyolxauhqui, Teteo Innan, Ce Calli, Ce Cuauhtli, Ce Mazatl, Ce Ozomatli, Chantico, Ilancueye, Ixnextli, Ometeotl

name: Coyolxauhqui
bio: Earth goddess who tried to kill Coatlicue. Her head was tossed in the sky by his brother, Huitzilopochtli, and became the moon, which represent cowardice for Aztecs..
source: Stone displayed in Templo Mayor Museum in Mexico City

name: Coyotlinaual
bio: God of featherworkds, also called amantecas. He's linked with Huehuecoyotl, another trickster god

name: Cuaxolotl
bio: Goddess of the hearth who gave birth to twins, as she wears a mask on the back of her head. She's the female counterpart of Xolotl and an aspect of Chantico.

name: Ehecatl
bio: Nagual of Quetzalcoatl which represents the west winds that bring rain. His breath helped to move the sun.
aspect: Quetzalcoatl, Tezcatlipoca, Chiconahui Ehecatl, Nahui Ehecatl

name: Huehuecoyotl
bio: Trickster and shapeshifter god, associated both with wildness and wisdom, lust and arts, especially dance and music. He was also a guide in Mictlan.

name: Huehueteotl
bio: Other aspect or name of Xiuthecuhtli, he's a fatherly figure and ancien god of hearth, the fire of life, and time.
spellings: Ueueteotl, Hiuhtecuctli, Ixcozauhqui, Cuezaltzin, Huehueteotl, Tata, Huehuetzin, Huehuetecutli, Huehuehteotl

name: Huehuecihuatl
bio: "Old woman", nagual of Omecihuatl, symbolizing time.

name: Huitzilopochtli
bio: God of war, thunderstorms, fire and sun. He's the original deity of the nomadic tribe of Mexica, also known as Aztecs. He was a warrior who need blood to win his battle against darkness.
spellings: Uitzilopochtli, Mextli, Mexitl, Inaquizcaotl, Mezitl, Omiteotl-Inaquizcaotl, Tetzauhteotl, Tetzahuitl, Yaotecuhtli, Yaotzin, Vitzilopuchtl, Mexih
aspect: Chiconahui Ehecatl, Amimitl, Patecatl, Painal, Opochtli, Ixtlilton, Tonatiuh, Tezcatlipoca, Camaxtli, Amapan, Mixcoatl, Uappatzin, Xiuhtecuhtli

name: Huixtocihuatl
bio: Fertility goddess of ocean who discovered salt. Could be a daughter or an aspect of Chalchiuhtlicue

name: Ilamacihuatl
bio: "Lady of Creation". Goddess of weavers, her roar signalled war. She's the elderly version of Chicomecoatl and associated with earth, death, and the milky way

name: Ilamatecuhtli
bio: "Lord of Creation". Another nagual of Ometecuhtli

name: Ilancueye
bio: One the several minor divinities of maize. She represented the withering corn husk surrounding a dried out maize cob

name: Ilhuicamina
bio: "He Who Shoots Arrows at the Heavens". Symbolizes the sun as one who destroys the stars.

name: Itzaccihuatl
bio: Representation of the great white mountain Iztactepetl, she's a mountain goddess, guardian of animals needed for food. Mexica affected by blindness would worship her.

name: Itzcuintli
bio: Sacred dog which guided the dead through Mictlan and guardian of home. This breed of hairless dog still actually exists.

name: Itzpapalotl
bio: Aztec goddess of sacrifice, associated with earth and fertility, who rules Tomoanchan, and leader of Cihuateteo and Tzitzimime. Her nahual is the butterfly, a manifestation of the dead souls

name: Itztapaltotec
bio: Minor god of Agriculture and fertility, nagual of Xipe Totec, but also a patron of precious metallurgists. He's probably related to Itztli, who is also depicted as a personified knife.

name: Itztlacoliuhqui
bio: Blind god of justice and punishment, associated with stone, cold and obsidian. Associated with night and north, he's a variant of Tezcatllipoca.
spellings: Itztlacoliuhqui-Ixquimilli,  Itzlacohuihqui, Itzlacoliuhqui, Itzlacoliuhque, Ixquimilli, Iztacoliuhqui

name: Itztli
bio: God of sacrifice and the sacred obsidian stone knives used for ritual slaying. Servant of Tezcatlipoca

name: Ixcozauhqui
bio: "Yellow-face", gods of merchants and nagual of Xiuhtecuhtli

name: Ixcuina
bio: Goddess of coton, associated, like her sisters, Tiacapan, Teicu, Tlaco and Xocotzin, to sex and filth. Nagual of Tlazolteotl.

name: Ixnextli
bio: Goddess of weavers and aspect of Xochiquetzal when she was expelled from paradise.

name: Ixquimilli
bio: God of darkness, justice and punishment. Protectors of the sorcereres., he was linked to both Itztlacoliuhqui and Tezcatlipoca.

name: Ixquitecatl
bio: God of sorcerers, healings arts, and pulque. Worshipped by members of the healing arts class as sorcerers were often brought in after more herb traditional healing methods failed.

name: Ixtlilton
bio: God of healing, dancing, festival and games. He played a role similar to the Sandman. Worshipped both as a agricultural and sexual god.

name: Macuil Cozcacuahtli
bio: One of the five gods of excess and pleasure, called Macuiltonaleque or Ahuiateteo, like drinking, gambling or sex. They represents the danger or overindulgence.

name: Macuil Cuetzpalin
bio: One of the five gods of excess and pleasure, called Macuiltonaleque or Ahuiateteo, like drinking, gambling or sex. They represents the danger or overindulgence.

name: Macuil Malinalli
bio: One of the five gods of excess and pleasure, called Macuiltonaleque or Ahuiateteo, like drinking, gambling or sex. They represents the danger or overindulgence.

name: Macuil Ocelotl
bio: One of the five gods of excess and pleasure, called Macuiltonaleque or Ahuiateteo, like drinking, gambling or sex. They represents the danger or overindulgence.

name: Macuil Tochtli
bio: One of the five gods of excess and pleasure, called Macuiltonaleque or Ahuiateteo, like drinking, gambling or sex. They represents the danger or overindulgence.

name: Macuil Xochitl
bio: One of the five gods of excess and pleasure, called Macuiltonaleque or Ahuiateteo, like drinking, gambling or sex. They represents the danger or overindulgence. Nagual of Xochipilli.
aspect: Xochiquetzal, Xochipilli, Centeotl, Ixtlilton, Huehuecoyotl, Mayahuel, Patecatl

name: Malinalxochi
bio: Underworld sorceress or goddess of snakes, scorpions and insects of the desert. Trying to slow down the journey of his half brother, Huiztilopochtli, and his people, she's abandonned and founded the city of Malinalco.

name: Matlalcueitl
bio: Tlaxcaltec goddess of running water, lakes, rivers, singing and divination. Nagual of Chalchiuhtlicue.

name: Mayahuel
bio: Goddess of the maguay plant and all his by-products, especially pulque. Said to have 400 breasts to nurture her children, she gave love to manking with her romance with Quetzalcoatl.
aspect: Tlazolteotl, Coatlicue, Centzon Totochtin, Macuil Cozcacuahtli, Macuil Cuetzpalin, Macuil Malinalli, Macuil Ocelotl, Macuil Tochtli, Macuil Xochitl, Ome Tochtli

name: Metztli
bio: Lowly god of darkness and worms who failed to sacrifice himslef to become the sun and, instead, became the moon.

name: Mictlancihuatl
bio: Mistress to Mictlantecuhtli and ruler of the deepest level of Mictlan. She was sacrified as a baby and magically grew to addulthood in the underworld.

name: Mictlantecuhtli
bio: God of death and lord of Mictlan, the main Aztec underworld. Living in complete darkness, he guard the bones of dead people but also babies before their birth.
spellings: Mictlantecuhtzi Tzontemoc, Mictlantli, Mictlantecahtli, Cuezallin, Ah Puch (mayan), Hunhau (mayan), Mictecacíhuatl, Mictlān Teuctli, Cuezal, Tocuilehua, Tlalchi Tonatiuh
aspect: Miquiztlitecuhtli, Chalchiuhtecolotl, Tonatiuh, Tlalchi Tonatiuh, Quetzalcoatl, Tlahuizcalpantecuhtli, Tepeyollotl, Itztlacoliuhqui, Itzcuintli, Chalchiutotolin, Xiuhtecuhtli, Tezcatlipoca, Ometecuhtli, Chalmecatecuhtli, Ometeotl, Xoaltecuhtli

name: Miquiztlitecuhtli
bio: God of violent death, such as suicide, accident, disease or homicide.

name: Mixcoatl
bio: Chichimec and Otomi god of hunting, war, fire, sky and the Milky Way. Depending on the sources, he can be the father of Huitzilopochtli and Quetzalcoatl or a new form of Tezcatlipoca.
spellings: Iztacmixcoatl, Icnopilli, Tlatlauhqui Tezcatl-Ihpoca, Opocheh, Ce Tecpatl Mixcoatl
aspect: Itzaccihuatl, Amimitl, Atlaua, Camaxtli, Tlahuizcalpantecuhtli, Opochtli, Huitzilopochtli, Tezcatlipoca, Xipe Totec, Yacatecuhtli

name: Nahui Ehecatl
bio: Second sun in the aztec cosmology, nagual of Ehecatl.

name: Nanahuatzin
bio: Lowly goddess who sacrified herself, by jumping into a fire, to become the sun god Tonatiuh. She represented self-sacrifice and courage.

name: Nappatecuhtli
bio: One of the Tlaloques (water gods), who invented the art of making mats, seats and cane screens with reed, sedge and canes.

name: Ocelotl
bio: God of all animals of land, sea and air, including humans. Protector of scouts and warriors, he's a nagual of Tezcatlipoca.

name: Omacatl
bio: God of feast and revelry, who could make men choke on food if he wasn't pleased by gifts.

name: Ome Tochtli
bio: God of pulque and drunkeness, depicted as a rabbit. He's the leader of the Centzon Totochtin

name: Omecihuatl
bio: Female representation of the creator god Ometeotl. God of the near and the distant, of substance and duality, she was mainly revered by the high classes, especially in poetry.
aspect: Mictlancihuatl, Oxomoco, Tonacacihuatl, Citlalicue, Coatlicue, Chalmecacihuatl, Huehuecihuatl, Ilamacihuatl

name: Ometecuhtli
bio: Male representation of the creator god Ometeotl. God of the near and the distant, of substance and duality, he was mainly revered by the high classes, especially poetry.
spellings: Ometeotl, Omeyotl, Ometeoltloque, Yohualli. Ometeoltloque, Ometecutli, Tloque Nahuaque, Citlatonac, Ometecuhtl, Ome Tochtli, Acalhuah, Ilhuicacihuatl, Ilhuicahuah, Ilhuicateotl
aspect: Xiuhtecuhtli, Tonacatecuhtli, Huehueteotl, Mictlantecuhtli, Citlalatonac, Chalmecatecuhtli, Ilamatecuhtli, Cipactonal

name: Ometeotl
bio: Androgynous entity, responsible for the creation of the world, on the back of Cipactli, and the gods, but not mankind.
aspect: Xiuhtecuhtli, Tonacatecuhtli, Huehueteotl, Mictlantecuhtli, Citlalatonac, Oxomoco, Mictlancihuatl, Cipactonal, Tonacacihuatl, Citlalicue, Coatlicue, Huehuecihuatl

name: Opochtli
bio: One of the Tlaloques (water gods), inventor of the, fishnet, fishing rod, harpoon, oar to row and snare to kill birds.

name: Otontecuhtli
bio: Mazahuah god of the fire-pit and protector of goldsmith. Associated with Xiuhtecuhtli.

name: Oxomoco
bio: First woman of the fifth sun created by Quetzalcoatl. Inventor of magic, she represents also the nightime and earth.

name: Painal
bio: Swift messenger of Huitzilopochtli, who call men to god to war. Captured prisoners were regularly offered to him.
spellings: Paynal, Painalton, Paynalton, payinal, payinalton, payinaltzin

name: Patecatl
bio: God of medecine and fertility who discovered, with his wife Mayahuel, pulque and especially its narcotic effect.

name: Piltzintecuhtli
bio: God of youth, symbolized by Mercury, and father of Centeotl. He was a manifestation of Tonatiuh or Xochipilli.

name: Piquete Zina
bio: Zapotec bat god who represented maize and fertility.

name: Popocatepetl
bio: Sacred volcano whose cult worshiped the earth, rain, water, and vegetation. Once a man, he was called away to war but his lover, Iztaccihuatl, died of grief. They ended up transformed into mourning mountains by the Gods.

name: Quetzalcoatl
field: fertility, pleasure, magic, subsistence, trade, craft
bio: One of the main divinity worshipped in Mesoamerica. He's  the god of agriculture, arts, love science and wind. Exiled by his brother Tezcatlipoca, his expected return has been seen, at first, as the arrival of Hernan Cortez in 1519.
spellings: Tlilpotonqui, Matl, Tlahuizcalpantecuhtli, Tlamacazqui, Topiltzin, Iztauhqui-Tezcatlipoca
aspect: Tlaloc, Chiconahui Ehecatl, Yacatecuhtli, Tlahuizcalpantecuhtli, Nanahuatzin, Atlaua, Xolotl, Xochipilli, Centeotl, Ehecatl, Tezcatlipoca, Tonatiuh

name: Quiahuitl
bio: One of the Tlaloque, which was worshipped in caves of hilltop temples by farmers for fertility. Nagual of Tlaloc.

name: Quilaztli
bio: Aspect of Coatlicue, associated with pregnancy, child birth and comestible plants.

name: Tecciztecatl
bio: Other name for Metztli. As the god of snails and worms, he failed to sacrifice himself to become the sun and was trasnformed into the moon. Symbol of cowardice.

name: Techalotl
bio: God of dance which was one of the Centzon Totochtin, deities associated with pulque. Could change himself into a fox-squirrel creature which lived in caves.

name: Tepeyollotl
bio: God of the heart of the mountain. Associated with jaguars, echoes, and earthquakes, he's an aspect of Tezcatlipoca.

name: Tepoztecatl
bio: One of the 400 Centzon Totochtin, the aztec gods of pulque. He was, at first, a local fertility deity from the town of Tepoztlan.

name: Teteo Innan
bio: Major group of female fertility deities, which combines terror and beauty, life and destruction. Seen as the mother of gods, they are associated with war and birth.
spellings: Tetevinan, Teteo Innan, Teteoh Innan, Toci, Tonantzin, Citlalcueyeh, Nantli,  Tlalli iyolloh, Tocih, Temazcaltecih, Tlalli, Tocitzin, Tocicuahuill, Temazcalteci, Tlalli Iyollo, Teteo-Innan-Toci, Chicomexochitl, Chalchiuhcihuatl, Teteoinnan

name: Tezcatlipoca
bio: Omnipotent god of rulers, sorcerers or warriors, he rules night, death, discord, conflict, temptation, change and destruction. Symbolised by the jaguar, he's a rival of Quetzalcoatl and one of the most complex aztec god.
spellings: Omacatl, Titlacauan/titlacahuan, Tezcatlanextia, Yaotl, Necoc Yaotl, Moyocoya, Necaualpilli, Miquizyaotl, Techimaltini, Teoxonecuilli, Tlacanexquimilli, Tlacatecolotl, Tliltecuhtli, Yayauhqui-Tezcatlipoca, Yoaltecuhtli, Yoalehecatl, Tlamatzincatl, Telpochtli, Moyocoyatzin, Monenegui, Teyocoyani, Teimatini, Yaotzin, Yaotl necoc, Moquequeloa, Nezaualpilli, Tlamatzincatl, Yoalli ehecatl, Chicoyaotl, Moquehqueloa, Moyocoya, Necocyaotzin, Nezahualpilli , Teonexquimilli, Teotlale, Tlanempopolo
aspect: Tlaloc, Huitzilopochtli, Quetzalcoatl, Piltzintecuhtli, Mixcoatl, Tezcatzoncatl, Omacatl, Ixquitecatl, Chiconahui Ehecatl, Chalchiuhtecolotl, Tlalchi Tonatiuh, Titlacahuan, Tepeyollotl, Tecciztecatl, Nappatecuhtli, Metztli, Ixquimilli, Itztlacoliuhqui, Huehuecoyotl, Ehecatl, Chalchiutotolin, Acxomocuil, Xipe Totec, Tloque Nahuaque, Mictlantecuhtli, Itztli, Malinalxochi, Mixcoatl, Ocelotl, Ome Tochtli, Tecciztecatl, Xiuhtecuhtli, Xoaltecuhtli, Xochipilli, Yacatecuhtli

name: Tezcatzoncatl
bio: Pulque god and one of the Centzon Totochtin, protectors of the intoxicated.

name: Titlacahuan
bio: Omnipotent god of destiny with malevolent power. One of the many aspects of Tezcatlipoca.

name: Tlacotzontli
bio: God of roads and protector for merchants depicted with a huge coat. To please him, they would cut themselves among roads and give him paper banners cover in blood.

name: Tlahuizcalpantecuhtli
bio: Destructive god of the Morning Star, dawn and east. An aspect of Quetzalcoatl which lives in Mictlan. By way of anecdote, he has the longest name in aztec pantheon.

name: Tlalchi Tonatiuh
bio: Chtonic underworld god. One of the aspect of Tonatiuh, when he makes it's daily journey from night to day.

name: Tlaloc
bio: Main aztec god, with Huitzilopochtli, who controls rain, hurricanes, fertility and lightning. He's also associated with springs, mountains and caves. Babies were drown to give him power.
spellings: Nuhualpilli, Oztoteot, Nonoalco, Nonohualco, Tlaloccantecutli, Tlaloctlamacazqui, Tlaloc Tlamacazqui, Epcoa, Epcoatl, Tlalocan Teuctli
aspect: Tecciztecatl, Popocatepetl, Yauhqueme, Tomiyauhtecuhtli, Nappatecuhtli, Xochipilli, Tzapatlan Tenen, Tlaloque, Tepoztecatl, Atlaua, Tlaltecuhtli, Quetzalcoatl, Centeotl, Piquete Zina, Quiahuitl, Tezcatlipoca

name: Tlaltecayoa
bio: One of the numerous god of pulque, also associated with the roundness of earth.

name: Tlaltecuhtli
bio: Sea monster creature, considered as the source of all living things. She's has to be kept benevolent by blood sacrifices, as she swallows the sun each night.
aspect: Tlaloc, Cipactli, Tonatiuh, Omecihuatl, Tepeyollotl, Teteo Innan

name: Tlatlauhqui Tezcatlipoca
bio: "Red Smoking Mirror", nagual of Tezcatlipoca, also identified with Xipe Totec.

name: Tlazolteotl
bio: Goddess of purification from filth, disease or excess, of sin, love, sex, regret and lamentation. She can turn into four aspects, a young moon, cruel and delightful, a sensual young woman, a priestess who bless married couples and a monster who destroy lovers and steal fortune.
spellings: Tlaelquani, Tlazolteotli, Ixcuina, Tlacolteutl, Teicu, Tiacapan, Tlaco, Tlahco, Tlazolcuani, Tlaculteotl, Xocotzin, Xucotzin, Caxxoch, Tlahui, Tlanzolteot, Ceolitzin, Ixcuinan, Tlahelcuani, Tlazolteocihuatl, Ixcuina, Ixcuiname
aspect: Coyolxauhqui, Teteo Innan, Chalmecacihuatl, Coatlicue, Ixcuina, Mayahuel

name: Tlazopilli
bio: Fertility god, and nagual of Xochipilli, worshipped during the seventh month of the Mexica calendar system.

name: Toci
bio: Nagual of Coatlicue and Xochitlicue associated with healing and venerated by curers of ailments and midwives
aspect: Coatlicue, Toci, Teteo Innan, Xochitlicue, Tlaltecuhtli

name: Tomiyauhtecuhtli
bio: Minor rain and fertility god associated with a mountain, probably close to Lake Chalco and Xochimilco.

name: Tonacacihuatl
bio: Creator goddess which seems to be a terrestrial representation of Omecihuatl.

name: Tonacatecuhtli
bio: Possibly a aspect of Ometecuhtli, associated with agriculture and fate. Depicted as a wrinkled man, he was the god of sustenance.

name: Tonantzin
bio: Honorific title for earth goddess like Toci, Coatlicue or Tlaltecuhtli. Her temple on the hill of Tepeyac seems to be the first place for the apparition of the Virgin of Guadalupe.

name: Tonatiuh
bio: Sun god, protector of the warriors and symbolized by the eagle, he presides the fifth (and actual) world age. The gods sacrificed themselves to create him and men has to give him enough energy, through blood, to battle against darkness.
aspect: Xiuhtecuhtli, Ixcozauhqui, Xochipilli, Nanahuatzin, Piltzintecuhtli, Centeotl, Quetzalcoatl, Tlaltecuhtli, Tlalchi Tonatiuh, Mictlantecuhtli, Huitzilopochtli, Ilhuicamina

name: Tzapatlan Tenen
bio: Goddess of nature, especially resin and turpentine which is used for healing ointments.
spellings: Tzapotla Tena, Tzapotlatena, Zapotlantenan, Zapotlan Tenan

name: Tzitzimime
bio: Monstruous form of the Cihuateteto, the spirits of women who had died while giving birth, especially dangerous during solar eclipses. Their ruler is Tzitzimitl or Itzpapalotl.

name: Tzitzimitl
bio: Aged goddess of inertia and alcohol which ruled the Tzitzimime, who lived in the night sky.

name: Uappatzin
bio: Patron deity of tlachtli, an aztec game where the ball represented the sun. Servant of Huitzilopochtli, is also associated with warfare.

name: Xilonen
bio: Local vegetation goddess, associated with corn. She's an aspect of the maize goddess Chicomecoatl, personifying the weet and young maize plant.

name: Xipe Totec
bio: Fierce god of agriculture, fertility, seasons and renewal, he was also a protector of gold workers, jewelers and warriors. He flayed himself to give humanity food, and was shown as wearing a flayed human skin
spellings: Tlatlauhqui Tezcatlipoca, Yopi,  Xipe-Totec-Tllatlauhquitezcatl, Tlatlauhqui Texcatl, Yohuallahuantzin, Oxipe, Teteucxipe, Tlacaxipehualiztli, Yohuallahuan, Yopih, Itzpapalotltotec, Tlatlauhqui-Tezcatlipoca, Tlatlauhcatezcatlipoca
aspect: Tezcatlipoca, Mixcoatl, Camaxtli, Centeotl, Chiconahui Ehecatl, Itztapaltotec

name: Xiuhcoatl
bio: Snake's embodiment of the sun's rays an emblem of the god Xiuhtecuhtli. Huitzilopochtli used hit to kill Coyolxauhqui and the Centzon Huitznahua.
source: Detail of the Aztec sun stone displayed in the National Anthropology Museum in Mexico City

name: Xiuhtecuhtli
bio: God of fire and time, protector of kings, warriors and pochtecas. One of the oldest cult in aztec mythology. He's also deeply conected with birth.
spellings: Xiuhteuctli, Tlalxictentica, Milintoc, Xiuhtototl, Ybebeyoban, Nauhyoteuctli, Nauhyoueye, Huehueteotl, Otonteuctli, Xocotl, Nauhyohuehue, Tlalxictenticah, Xippilli, Xippil, Cuecaltzin, Huehuetiliztli, Viveteutl, Nauhyoteuctli
aspect: Ixcozauhqui, Ilhuicamina, Coyotlinaual, Ahkinshok, Xiuhcoatl, Ixtlilton, Tezcatlipoca, Huitzilopochtli, Otontecuhtli, Huehuecoyotl, Yacatecuhtli, Ometecuhtli, Tonatiuh, Huehueteotl, Ometeotl

name: Xoaltecuhtli
bio: God of night, sleep and dreams and messenger of Mictlantecuhtli.

name: Xochipilli
bio: Young god of feasting, painting, dancing, games, and writing. He represents the masculine aspect of eroticism, with its pleasures, dangers and responsabilities.
spellings: Xochipili, Chicomexochitl, Macuil Xochitl, Piltzintecuhtli-Tonatiuh, Papaloxahual-Xochipilli, Xochipilli-Centeotl, Xochiquetzal
aspect: Xochiquetzal, Tlaloc, Centeotl, Xiuhtecuhtli, Macuil Xochitl, Tonatiuh, Tezcatlipoca, Quetzalcoatl, Chalchiuhtlatonac, Macuil Cozcacuahtli, Macuil Cuetzpalin, Macuil Malinalli, Macuil Ocelotl, Macuil Tochtli, Macuil Xochitl, Piltzintecuhtli, Tlazopilli

name: Xochiquetzal
bio: Goddess of female sexuality, prostitutes, homosexuals, young mothers, flowers, pleasure and craft (embroiders, weavers, silversmiths and sculptors)
aspect: Xochipilli, Ce Mazatl, Coatlicue, Ilamacihuatl, Ixnextli, Yacatecuhtli

name: Xolotl
bio: Canine companion and/or twin brother of Quetzalcoatl. God of twins, fire, sickness, deformity and bad luck, he accompanied the dead to Mictlan and nourrished the first men of the fifth sun.

name: Yacapitzahuac
bio: Minor god of commerce and merchants.

name: Yacatecuhtli
bio: God of merchants and travelers, especially pochtecas. Depicted as a man with a long nose and a stick, he opens the way for gods to travel to the mortal world and also clears a path for the imperial armies.
spellings: Yactecuhtli, Yiacatecutli, Yacacoliuhqui, Ollohqueh, Iyahcateuctli, Yacapitzahuac, Tacatecutli, Ek Chuah, Ekchuah
aspect: Macuil Tochtli, Macuil Ocelotl, Coyotlinaual, Tepoztecatl, Nappatecuhtli, Xochiquetzal, Tzapatlan Tenen, Itztapaltotec, Centeotl, Otontecuhtli, Tlacotzontli, Ixcozauhqui, Amimitl, Huehuecoyotl, Quetzalcoatl, Titlacahuan, Huixtocihuatl, Acxomocuil, Chiconahui Itzcuintli, Xiuhtecuhtli, Tezcatlipoca, Mixcoatl

name: Yauhqueme
bio: God of milkweed, asteraceae, rosaceae, gutiferous and hypericaceae, identified as one of the four Tlaloque.

name: Yohual Tonatiuh
bio: Form of Tonatiuh, the sun god, when he makes its way from day to night.

name: Yohualticitl
bio: Goddess of steam baths, which were strongly related to pregnant women with the symbolic of the womb.

name: Youaltepuztli
bio: Nocturnal collecting-soul monster, depicted as a beheaded cadaver with an hole in his torso, opening and closing rapidly  with a terrific sound. The bravest could try pick his black heart and crush it to make him disappear.

name: Zacatzontli
bio: God of roads and protector for merchants.
